Of course this cannot replace good testing, but I don't think we are doing
perfect testing either, so I want to be able to survive a little glitch, not
halt the entire server. Only counterpoint I see is that when you crash the
entire JVM (thus app server) the bug will be fixed with much higher priority
because you'll have management over you. Not sur it's a win ;)

Neither of you ever experiences a server halt that could have been avoided
by simply catching some throwables?. I did. Wrongly installed library on one
on the app servers in a cluster. Only that little rarely used feature didn't
work. We got an alert, fixed it, and here we go. You think it's preferable
to get the entire JVM to exit? No talking about a JVM serving one client
here. A lot of clients on the same machine. It would be like you have a CGI
that crashes leading to a stop of the entire apache server.

I'm surprised I'm the only one doing that sort of stuff. Anybody doing web
developpement and not feeling the need for this (Catching a wide range of
exceptions) ?

Sometimes you just want to do

try {
this();
}catch (AnythingThatCouldGoWrongReallyAnything t) {
logIt(t);
//go on with your life, since this() was just a best-effort feature, no
garantee, not important, does not justify aborting the transaction.
}


mathieu

Sounds a little like catch-all-life-insurance to allow you to be lazy
in design or implementation?

Be careful, you can not catch everything like this, for examlple a
stack overflow due to infinite recursion just crashed the JVM process
on my machine yesterday.
